created_at.description: When the event was created, in Unix epoch format.

description.description: A brief description of the event (for example, its agenda). The description might be returned as an HTML string depending on how the provider formats it.
description.example: Time for us to sync weekly on any new project changes

hide_participants.description: (Not supported for iCloud or EWS events) When `true`, hides the event's list of participants.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

html_link.description: (Not supported for EWS events) A link to the event on the provider.

ical_uid.description:
A unique ID that you can use to identify events across calendaring systems, in
[iCalendar format](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.4.7).
Recurring events might share the same ID.

Can be `null` for events synced before the year 2020.

id.description: The ID of the event. Generally, event IDs are unique to each user. However, Google maintains the same event ID for an event regardless of the user querying it.

location.description: The location of the event (for example, a physical address or the name of a meeting room).

master_event_id.description:
If the event is an instance of a recurring event series, this field contains the main (master)
event's ID.

metadata.description:
The metadata associated with the object. For more information, see
[metadata](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--metadata).

organizer.description: An object that contains information about an event's organizer.

participants.title: Participants
participants.description:
An array of participants invited to the event. The organizer doesn't need to be explicitly
included in this list.

comment.description: A comment about the participant (for example, their nickname).

name.description: The participant's full name. Not all providers store participant names, so this field may be null, or an empty string.

status.description: The participant's attendance status.

resources.description: An array of room resources added to the event.

read_only.description:
If `true`, indicates that the event is read-only. The provider sets the `read_only` value based on
the connected calendar, and you cannot modify it.

If the calendar is read-only, all events on the calendar have `read_only` set to `true`.

reminders.description:

use_default.description:

- **Google**: Generates a `popup`-style reminder 10 minutes before the event begins.
- **Microsoft**: Generates a reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.
- **iCloud**: Does not generate a reminder.
- **EWS**: Generates a `display`-style reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.

import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.*

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
  val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>")
  val queryParams = UpdateEventQueryParams("<CALENDAR_ID>", false)

  val requestBody : UpdateEventRequest = UpdateEventRequest.Builder().
      location("Nylas' Theatre").
      build()

  val response : Response<Event> = nylas.events().update(
      "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>",
      "<EVENT_ID>",
      requestBody,
      queryParams)
}

the `show_cancelled` query parameter.

Microsoft deletes events immediately.

from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

import os
import sys
from nylas import Client

nylas = Client(
    os.environ.get('NYLAS_API_KEY'),
    os.environ.get('NYLAS_API_URI')
)

grant_id = os.environ.get("NYLAS_GRANT_ID")
event_id = os.environ.get("EVENT_ID")

event = nylas.events.destroy(
    grant_id,
    event_id,
    query_params={
      "calendar_id": os.environ.get("CALENDAR_ID")
    }
)

print(event)

parameters.name: grant_id
parameters.description: ID of the grant to access. Use `/me/` to refer to the grant associated with an access token.

parameters.name: event_id
parameters.description:
ID of the event to access. Nylas recommends you URL-encode this field, or you might receive a
[`404` error](/docs/api/errors/400-response/) if the ID contains special characters (for
example, `#`).

post.description:
This endpoint allows you to respond to events that you're added to as a participant. You cannot
directly update events as a participant, because you're not the owner/organizer of the event.

For most events on EWS, if you decline the event by sending a "no" RSVP response, it's removed from
your calendar. If an EWS administrator disabled the option to remove declined events from calendars,
the event remains on the calendar with the "no" RSVP status.

Nylas sends calendar RSVPs as email updates. If your application does not implement the
[scopes that allow you to send email messages](/docs/v3/email/scopes/#email-api-scopes), Nylas
updates the RSVP for the event and returns a `200` error message. Event participants on the same
provider will see the update, but participants on other providers will not.

parameters.name: calendar_id
parameters.description:
Filter for the specified calendar ID.

(Not supported for iCloud) You can use `primary` to query the end user's primary calendar.

status.description: A participant's RSVP status for the event.

send_ics_error.description:
If an error occurs while sending an updated ICS file to the organizer of an event,
Nylas returns an error message in this field. The event is still updated, but the
ICS file is _not_ sent to the organizer.

type.description: The type of error that occurred.

message.description: A human-readable message with details about the error.

Request had invalid authentication credentials. Expected OAuth 2 access token, login cookie or other valid authentication credential.

error.message: Too many requests, please try again shortly.

import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.RsvpStatus
import com.nylas.models.SendRsvpQueryParams
import com.nylas.models.SendRsvpRequest

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
  val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>")
  val requestBody : SendRsvpRequest = SendRsvpRequest(RsvpStatus.YES)
  val queryParams : SendRsvpQueryParams = SendRsvpQueryParams("<CALENDAR_ID>")

  val rsvp = nylas.events().sendRsvp(
      "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>",
      "<EVENT_ID>",
      requestBody,
      queryParams)

  print(rsvp)
}

parameters.name: grant_id
parameters.description: ID of the grant to access. Use `/me/` to refer to the grant associated with an access token.

next_cursor.description: The next cursor for the request.

bcc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was BCC'd to. For received messages, this is nearly always empty.

body.description: The full HTML message body. Email messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.
body.example: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!

cc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was CC'd to.

date.description: Unix timestamp that represents when _the mail server_ received the email message. This may be different from the unified `Date` header in a raw Message object.

attachments.description: An array of Attachment objects, if the email message includes attachments.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) that the email message appears in. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

from.description: A list of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent from. This is usually one pair only, but can be many.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response (in this case, `message`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

schedule_id.description: The ID of the scheduled email message. Nylas returns the `schedule_id` if `send_at` is set.

snippet.description: A short snippet (the first 100 characters, with HTML tags removed) of the email message body. This is useful for displaying a preview of the message.
snippet.example: You have been invited to the following event. Welcome! WhenThu Oct 28, 2021 7am - 8am Eastern Time - Toronto Joining info

starred.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been starred by the user. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

subject.description: The subject of the email message.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. Every email message is associated with a thread, whether that thread contains only one message or many. If this is a new email message, Nylas assigns a `thread_id` to it.

to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent to.

unread.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been read by the user.

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

data.body: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!
data.snippet: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!
data.subject: Hello from Nylas!

‚ö†Ô∏è Your end users receive a large number of email messages. If you encounter 429 errors or provider rate limits when listing all email messages, Nylas recommends you set the limit parameter to 20 and add query parameters to your request to limit the results.

parameters.description: Return items with a matching subject. The filter is case insensitive and will match partial subjects.

parameters.name: any_email
parameters.description: Return email messages that were sent to or received from this comma-separated list of email addresses (for example, `mail1@example.com,mail2@example.com`). You can specify a maximum of 25 email addresses.

parameters.name: to
parameters.description: Return items containing email messages sent to this email address.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: Return items containing email messages sent from this email address.

parameters.name: cc
parameters.description: Return items containing email messages that were CC'd to this email address.

parameters.name: bcc
parameters.description: Return items containing email messages that were BCC'd to this email address, likely sent from the parent account. (Most SMTP gateways remove BCC information.)

parameters.name: in
parameters.description:
Filter for email messages in a specific folder. Nylas uses the Folders API for both folders
and Google's "labels". For more information, see the
[Folders reference](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#tag--Folders).

Google does not support filtering using folder names. You must use the folder ID.

parameters.name: unread
parameters.description: Return items with one or more unread email messages.

parameters.name: starred
parameters.description: Return items with one or more starred email messages. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

parameters.name: thread_id
parameters.description: Return items with a matching `thread_id`.

parameters.name: received_before
parameters.description: Return email messages received before this Unix timestamp.

parameters.name: received_after
parameters.description: Return email messages received after this Unix timestamp.

parameters.name: has_attachment
parameters.description: Return email messages with attachments.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Return messages with headers by specifying `include_headers`. Not supported for IMAP, iCloud, or Yahoo. For Microsoft the message headers are always empty if the message is in the sent folder. For EWS, message headers might be empty if the message was sent by the current email address.

parameters.name: search_query_native
parameters.description:
A URL-encoded provider-specific query string. Supported for
[Google](https://support.google.com/mail/answer/7190?hl=en),
[Microsoft Graph](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/search-query-parameter?tabs=http#using-search-on-message-collections),
and [EWS](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/lwef/-search-2x-wds-aqsreference).

You can only use a limited set of query parameters with `search_query_native`, depending on
the provider:

- **Microsoft**: `in`, `limit`, and `page_token`
- **Google**: `in`, `limit`, `page_token`, and `thread_id`
- **EWS**: Any parameter _except_ `thread_id`

You can also use
[Microsoft Graph `$filter` queries](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/filter-query-parameter)
in this parameter. Create your filter query, prefix it with `$filter=`, then URL-encode it.

For more information, see
[Searching with Nylas](/docs/dev-guide/search/#search-messages-and-threads-using-search_query_native).

example1.description: Google query string for messages with subject "foo" or "bar".

example2.description: Microsoft Graph query for messages using the `$filter` syntax.

x-code-samples.label: Ruby SDK
x-code-samples.source:
require 'nylas'

# Initialize Nylas client
nylas = Nylas::Client.new(
	api_key: "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
)

messages, _ = nylas.messages.list(identifier: "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>")
messages.each {|message|
	puts "[#{Time.at(message[:date]).strftime("%d/%m/%Y at %H:%M:%S")}] | \
#{message[:id]} | \
#{message[:subject]} | \
#{message[:folders]}"
}

parameters.name: grant_id
parameters.description: ID of the grant to access. Use `/me/` to refer to the grant associated with an access token.

parameters.name: message_id
parameters.description:
ID of the email message to access. Nylas recommends you URL-encode this field, or you might
receive a [`404` error](/docs/api/errors/400-response/) if the ID contains special characters
(for example, `#`).

bcc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was BCC'd to. For received messages, this is nearly always empty.

body.description: The full HTML message body. Email messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.
body.example: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!

cc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was CC'd to.

date.description: Unix timestamp that represents when _the mail server_ received the email message. This may be different from the unified `Date` header in a raw Message object.

attachments.description: An array of Attachment objects, if the email message includes attachments.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) that the email message appears in. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

from.description: A list of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent from. This is usually one pair only, but can be many.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response (in this case, `message`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

schedule_id.description: The ID of the scheduled email message. Nylas returns the `schedule_id` if `send_at` is set.

snippet.description: A short snippet (the first 100 characters, with HTML tags removed) of the email message body. This is useful for displaying a preview of the message.
snippet.example: You have been invited to the following event. Welcome! WhenThu Oct 28, 2021 7am - 8am Eastern Time - Toronto Joining info

starred.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been starred by the user. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

subject.description: The subject of the email message.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. Every email message is associated with a thread, whether that thread contains only one message or many. If this is a new email message, Nylas assigns a `thread_id` to it.

to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent to.

unread.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been read by the user.

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

data.snippet: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!
data.subject: Hello from Nylas!

parameters.description: Return an email message with its headers by specifying `include_headers`. If this is a Microsoft message in the sent folder, the headers are always empty.

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) to apply, overwriting all folders previously associated with the message. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

import os
import sys
from nylas import Client

nylas = Client(
    os.environ.get('NYLAS_API_KEY'),
    os.environ.get('NYLAS_API_URI')
)

grant_id = os.environ.get("NYLAS_GRANT_ID")
folder_id = os.environ.get("FOLDER_ID")
message_id = os.environ.get("MESSAGE_ID")

message = nylas.messages.update(
  grant_id,
  message_id,
  request_body={
    "folders": [folder_id]
  }
)

print(message)

import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.UpdateMessageRequest

fun main(args: Array<String>) {

    val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(
        apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
    )

    val request : UpdateMessageRequest =
        UpdateMessageRequest.Builder().
        unread(true).
        starred(true).
        build()

    val message = nylas.messages().update(
        "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>",
        "<MESSAGE_ID>", request
    )
    print(message)
}

put.description:
This endpoint removes extra information from email messages. Instead of needing to parse through images, attachments, and HTML pages,  Nylas removes the information you don't need and returns what you _do_ need.
**Note**: Nylas removes all the extra information, such as `<script>` and `<style>` tags, regardless of the configuration.

parameters.name: select
parameters.description:
Specify fields that you want Nylas to return, as a comma-separated list (for example,
`select=id,updated_at`). This allows you to receive only the portion of object data that you're
interested in. You can use `select` to optimize response size and reduce latency by limiting queries
to only the information that you need.

message_id.description: IDs of the email messages to clean.

ignore_links.description: If `true`, removes link-related tags (`<a>`) from the email message while keeping the text.

ignore_images.description: If `true`, removes images from the email message.

images_as_markdown.description: If `true`, converts images in the email message to Markdown.

ignore_tables.description: If `true`, removes table-related tags (`<table>`, `<th>`, `<td>`, `<tr>`) from the email message while keeping rows.

remove_conclusion_phrases.description: If `true`, removes phrases such as "Best" and "Regards" in the email message signature.

x-code-samples.label: cURL
x-code-samples.source:
curl --request PUT \
--url 'https://api.us.nylas.com/v3/grants/NYLAS_GRANT_ID/messages/clean' \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--header 'Accept: application/json' \
--header 'Authorization: Bearer <NYLAS_API_KEY_OR_ACCESS_TOKEN>' \
--data '{
  "message_id": ["18df98cadcc8534a"],
  "ignore_links": false,
  "ignore_images": false,
  "images_as_markdown": true,
  "ignore_tables": true,
  "remove_conclusion_phrases": true
}'

parameters.name: grant_id
parameters.description: ID of the grant to access. Use `/me/` to refer to the grant associated with an access token.

post.description:
You can send an email message immediately, or schedule it to send later.

- To send an email message immediately, omit the `send_at` field.
- To schedule an email message, set the `send_at` field to the time when you want it to be sent,
in Unix epoch format.

(Google and Microsoft Graph only) When scheduling a message, you can set `use_draft` to `true`
to save the email message in the end user's Drafts folder until it is sent.

For more information about scheduled send, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/).

### Limitations

Microsoft Graph and iCloud do not support the `List-Unsubscribe-Post` or `List-Unsubscribe` headers.
Because of this, Nylas can't support these headers for messages sent from Microsoft Graph and iCloud
accounts.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. Every email message is associated with a thread, whether that thread contains only one message or many. If this is a new email message, Nylas assigns a `thread_id` to it.

to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent to.

unread.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been read by the user.

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

bcc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was BCC'd to. For received messages, this is nearly always empty.

body.description: The full HTML message body. Email messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.
body.example: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!

cc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was CC'd to.

date.description: Unix timestamp that represents when _the mail server_ received the email message. This may be different from the unified `Date` header in a raw Message object.

attachments.description: An array of Attachment objects, if the email message includes attachments.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) that the email message appears in. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

from.description: A list of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent from. This is usually one pair only, but can be many.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response (in this case, `message`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

schedule_id.description: The ID of the scheduled email message. Nylas returns the `schedule_id` if `send_at` is set.

snippet.description: A short snippet (the first 100 characters, with HTML tags removed) of the email message body. This is useful for displaying a preview of the message.
snippet.example: You have been invited to the following event. Welcome! WhenThu Oct 28, 2021 7am - 8am Eastern Time - Toronto Joining info

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. Every email message is associated with a thread, whether that thread contains only one message or many. If this is a new email message, Nylas assigns a `thread_id` to it.

x-code-samples.label: cURL
Node.js SDK
Python SDK
x-code-samples.source:
import os
import sys
from nylas import Client
from nylas import utils

nylas = Client(
    "<NYLAS_API_KEY>",
    "<NYLAS_API_URI>"
)

grant_id = "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>"
email = "<EMAIL>"

attachment = utils.file_utils.attach_file_request_builder("Nylas_Logo.png")

message = nylas.messages.send(
  grant_id,
  request_body={
    "to": [{ "name": "Name", "email": email }],
    "reply_to": [{ "name": "Name", "email": email }],
    "subject": "Your Subject Here",
    "body": "Your email body here.",
    "attachments": [attachment]
  }
)

print(message)

x-code-samples.source: import com.nylas.NylasClient import com.nylas.models.* import com.nylas.util.FileUtils fun main(args: Array) { val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient( apiKey = "" ) val attachment: CreateAttachmentRequest = FileUtils.attachFileRequestBuilder("src/main/kotlin/Nylas_Logo.png") val options = TrackingOptions("hey just testing", true, true, true) val emailNames : List = listOf(EmailName("john.doe@example.com", "John Doe")) val requestBody : SendMessageRequest = SendMessageRequest.Builder(emailNames). subject("Hey Reaching Out with Nylas"). body("Hey I would like to track this link My Example Link"). trackingOptions(options). attachments(listOf(attachment)). build() val email = nylas.messages().send("", requestBody) print(email.data) }

delete.description:
Cancels the send schedule for a scheduled email message. You can use this endpoint up to 10 seconds before the email message has reached its `send_at` time. If you make a `DELETE` request less than 10 seconds before the `send_at` time, Nylas cannot guarantee the schedule will be cancelled successfully.
You _cannot_ use this endpoint to un-send an email message.

parameters.name: scheduleId
parameters.description: The ID of the send schedule you want to cancel.

provider_error.message: The mailbox is either inactive, soft-deleted, or is hosted on-premise.

Best regards,

import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.ComposeMessageRequest

fun main(args: Array<String>) {

    val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(
        apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
    )

    val requestBody : ComposeMessageRequest =
    ComposeMessageRequest("Reply")
    val message = nylas.messages().smartCompose().composeMessageReply("<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>",
    "<MESSAGE_ID>", requestBody)
    print(message.data.suggestion)

}

If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) that the email message appears in. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

from.description: A list of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent from. This is usually one pair only, but can be many.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response (in this case, `message`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

schedule_id.description: The ID of the scheduled email message. Nylas returns the `schedule_id` if `send_at` is set.

snippet.description: A short snippet (the first 100 characters, with HTML tags removed) of the email message body. This is useful for displaying a preview of the message.
snippet.example: You have been invited to the following event. Welcome! WhenThu Oct 28, 2021 7am - 8am Eastern Time - Toronto Joining info

starred.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been starred by the user. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

subject.description: The subject of the email message.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. Every email message is associated with a thread, whether that thread contains only one message or many. If this is a new email message, Nylas assigns a `thread_id` to it.

to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent to.

unread.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been read by the user.

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

latest_draft_or_message.description: The latest email message or draft in the thread.

has_attachments.description: When `true`, indicates that the email message has attachments.

has_drafts.description: When `true`, indicates that the email message is a draft.

earliest_message_date.description:
The date when the earliest or first email message in the thread was sent or received, in Unix
epoch format.

latest_message_received_date.description:
The date when the most recent incoming email message in the thread was received, in Unix epoch
format.

latest_message_sent_date.description:
The date when the most recent outgoing email message in the thread was sent, in Unix epoch
format.

participants.description: A sub-object that contains the names and email addresses of all participants in the thread.

snippet.description:
A short snippet (the first 100 characters, with HTML tags removed) of the body of the last
received email message. This is useful for displaying a preview of an email message.
snippet.example: jnlnnn --Sent with Nylas

starred.description: When `true`, indicates that the thread is starred. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

subject.description: The subject line of the thread.

unread.description: When `false`, indicates that all email messages in the thread have been read.

message_ids.description: An array of IDs for all email messages in the thread.

draft_ids.description: An array of IDs for all drafts in the thread.

folders.description:
An array of folder IDs for all folders that the email messages in the thread appear in.

Microsoft email messages can only be in one folder at a time.

Google email messages can be in multiple folders.

get.description:
Returns all threads.

‚ö†Ô∏è Your end users might receive a large number of threaded email messages. If you encounter 429 errors or provider rate limits when listing all threads, Nylas recommends you set the limit parameter to 20 and add query parameters to your request to limit the results.

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description:
The maximum number of objects to return. See [pagination](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--pagination)
for more information.

parameters.name: page_token
parameters.description: An identifier that specifies which page of data to return. You can get this value from the `next_cursor` response field. See [Pagination](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--pagination) for more information.

parameters.name: subject
parameters.description: Return items with a matching subject. The filter is case insensitive and will match partial subjects.

parameters.name: any_email
parameters.description:
Filter for threads that contain email messages sent to or received from the email addresses
in the comma-separated list. You may specify a maximum of 25 email addresses per query.

parameters.name: to
parameters.description: Filter for threads that contain email messages sent to the specified email address.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description: Filter for threads that contain email messages sent from the specified email address.

parameters.name: cc
parameters.description: Filter for threads that contain email messages CC'd to the specified email address.

parameters.name: bcc
parameters.description:
Filter for threads that contain email messages BCC'd to the specified email address. Because
most SMTP gateways remove BCC information from sent email messages, any email messages that
Nylas returns are likely sent from the parent account.

parameters.name: in
parameters.description:
Filter for threads in a specific folder. Nylas uses the Folders API for both folders and
Google's "labels". For more information, see the
[Folders reference](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#tag--Folders).

Google does not support filtering using folder names. You must use the folder ID.

parameters.name: unread
parameters.description: Filter for threads that contain one or more unread email messages.

parameters.name: starred
parameters.description: Filter for threads that contain one or more starred email messages.

parameters.name: latest_message_before
parameters.description:
Filter for threads whose most recent email message was received before the specified time, in
Unix epoch format.

parameters.name: latest_message_after
parameters.description:
Filter for threads whose most recent email message was received after the specified time, in
Unix epoch format.

parameters.name: has_attachment
parameters.description: Filter for threads that include attachments.

parameters.name: search_query_native
parameters.description:
A URL-encoded provider-specific query string. Supported for
[Google](https://support.google.com/mail/answer/7190?hl=en),
[Microsoft Graph](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/search-query-parameter?tabs=http#using-search-on-message-collections),
and [EWS](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/lwef/-search-2x-wds-aqsreference).

For most providers, you can only use `in` and the
[pagination parameters](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--pagination) (`limit` and `page_token`) with
`search_query_native`. For EWS, however, these restrictions don't apply.

You can also use
[Microsoft Graph `$filter` queries](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/filter-query-parameter)
in this parameter. Create your filter query, prefix it with `$filter=`, then URL-encode it.

For more information, see
[Searching with Nylas](/docs/dev-guide/search/#search-messages-and-threads-using-search_query_native).

example1.description: Google query string for threads with subject "foo" or "bar".

example2.description: Microsoft Graph query for threads using the `$filter` syntax.

parameters.name: select
parameters.description:
Specify fields that you want Nylas to return, as a comma-separated list (for example,
`select=id,updated_at`). This allows you to receive only the portion of object data that you're
interested in. You can use `select` to optimize response size and reduce latency by limiting queries
to only the information that you need.

x-code-samples.label: cURL
x-code-samples.source:
curl --request GET \
  --url "https://api.us.nylas.com/v3/grants/<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>/threads?limit=5" \
  --header 'Accept: application/json' \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer <NYLAS_API_KEY>' \
  --header 'Content-Type: application/json'

x-code-samples.label: Node.js SDK
Python SDK
x-code-samples.source:
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

import os
import sys
from nylas import Client

nylas = Client(
    os.environ.get('NYLAS_API_KEY'),
    os.environ.get('NYLAS_API_URI')
)

grant_id = os.environ.get("NYLAS_GRANT_ID")

threads = nylas.threads.list(
  grant_id,
  query_params={
    "limit": 5
  }
)

print(threads)

x-code-samples.label: Ruby SDK
x-code-samples.source:
require 'nylas'

nylas = Nylas::Client.new(api_key: "<NYLAS_API_KEY>")
query_params = { limit: 5 }
threads, _ = nylas.threads.list(identifier: "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>", query_params: query_params)

threads.map.with_index { |thread, i|
  puts("Thread #{i}")
  participants = thread[:participants]

  participants.each{ |participant|
    puts(
      "Subject: #{thread[:subject]} | "\
      "Participant: #{participant[:name]} | "\
      "Email: #{participant[:email]}"
    )
  }
}

put.description:
Update a specific thread.

When you make a `PUT` request, Nylas replaces all data in the nested object with the information
included in your request. For more information, see
[Updating objects](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--updating-objects).

parameters.description:
Specify fields that you want Nylas to return, as a comma-separated list (for example,
`select=id,updated_at`). This allows you to receive only the portion of object data that you're
interested in. You can use `select` to optimize response size and reduce latency by limiting queries
to only the information that you need.

starred.description: When `true`, indicates that the thread is starred.

unread.description: When `false`, indicates that all email messages in the thread have been read.

folders.description:
The IDs of the folders to apply to the thread. This overwrites all previously assigned
folders for all email messages in the thread.

x-code-samples.label: Java SDK
Kotlin SDK
x-code-samples.source:
import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.UpdateThreadRequest

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
  val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(
      apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
  )

  val requestBody: UpdateThreadRequest =
      UpdateThreadRequest.
      Builder().
      unread(true).
      starred(true).
      build()

  val thread = nylas.threads().update("<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>", "<THREAD_ID>", requestBody)

  print("${thread.data.id} ${thread.data.unread} ${thread.data.starred} ")
}

considered a "soft delete", because the API request doesn't empty the trash.

parameters.description: Return items containing email messages sent to this email address.

parameters.name: cc
parameters.description: Return items containing email messages that were CC'd to this email address.

parameters.name: bcc
parameters.description: Return items containing messages that were BCC'd to this email address, likely sent from the parent account. (Most SMTP gateways remove BCC information, so this appears only if the user sent the email message, or received it because they were on the BCC list.)

parameters.name: starred
parameters.description: Return items with one or more starred email messages. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

parameters.name: thread_id
parameters.description: Return items with a matching `thread_id`.

parameters.name: has_attachment
parameters.description: Return items with attachments.

x-code-samples.source:
require 'nylas'

nylas = Nylas::Client.new(
	api_key: "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
)

drafts, _ = nylas.drafts.list(identifier: "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>")
drafts.each {|draft|
	puts "[#{Time.at(draft[:date]).strftime("%d/%m/%Y at %H:%M:%S")}] | \
#{draft[:id]} | \
#{draft[:subject]} | \
#{draft[:folders]}"
}

Python SDK
x-code-samples.source:
import os
import sys
from nylas import Client
from nylas import utils

nylas = Client(
    "<NYLAS_API_KEY>",
    "<NYLAS_API_URI")
)

grant_id = "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>"
email = "<EMAIL>"

attachment = utils.file_utils.attach_file_request_builder("Nylas_Logo.png")

draft = nylas.drafts.create(
  grant_id,
  request_body={
    "to": [{ "name": "Name", "email": email }],
    "reply_to": [{ "name": "Name", "email": email }],
    "subject": "Your Subject Here",
    "body": "Your email body here.",
    "attachments": [attachment]
  }
)

print(draft)

x-code-samples.label: Ruby SDK
x-code-samples.source:
require 'nylas'	

# Initialize Nylas client
nylas = Nylas::Client.new(
	api_key: "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
)

file = Nylas::FileUtils.attach_file_request_builder("Nylas_Logo.png")

request_body = {
    subject: "From Nylas",
    body: 'This email was sent using the ' +
              'Nylas email API. ' + 
              'Visit https://nylas.com for details.',
    to: [{ name: "Dorothy Vaughan", 
            email: "dorothy@example.com"}],
    cc: [{ name: "George Washington Carver", 
            email: "carver@example.com"}],
    bcc: [{ name: "Albert Einstein", 
            email: "al@example.com"}],
    reply_to: [{ name: "Stephanie Kwolek", 
            email: "skwolek@example.com"}],
   tracking_options: {label: "hey just testing", 
        opens: true, 
        links: true,
        thread_replies: true},
   attachments: [file]        
}

draft, _ = nylas.drafts.create(identifier: "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>", request_body: request_body)
puts "Draft \"#{draft[:subject]}\" was created with ID: #{draft[:id]}"

x-code-samples.label: Java SDK
Kotlin SDK
x-code-samples.source:
import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.*
import com.nylas.util.FileUtils

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
  val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(
      apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
  )

  val attachment: CreateAttachmentRequest = FileUtils.attachFileRequestBuilder("src/main/kotlin/Nylas_Logo.png")

  val requestBody = CreateDraftRequest(
      to = listOf(EmailName("swag@example.com", "Nylas")),
      cc = listOf(EmailName("dorothy@example.com", "Dorothy Vaughan")),
      bcc = listOf(EmailName("Lamarr@example.com", "Hedy Lamarr")),
      subject = "With Love, from Nylas",
      body = "This email was sent using the Nylas Email API. Visit https://nylas.com for details.",
      attachments = listOf(attachment)
  )

  val draft = nylas.drafts().create(dotenv["NYLAS_GRANT_ID"], requestBody).data

  print("Draft " + draft.subject + " was created with ID: " + draft.id)
}

import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.*

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
	val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(
			apiKey = dotenv["NYLAS_API_KEY"]
	)

	val draft = nylas.drafts().find(dotenv["NYLAS_GRANT_ID"], "<DRAFT_ID>")

	println("${draft.data.id} | " +
			"${draft.data.to?.get(0)?.email} | " +
			"${draft.data.subject}")
}

x-code-samples.source:
import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.*
import com.nylas.util.FileUtils

fun main(args: Array<String>) {

    val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(
        apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
    )

    val attachment: CreateAttachmentRequest = FileUtils.attachFileRequestBuilder("src/main/kotlin/Nylas_Logo.png")

    val requestBody = UpdateDraftRequest(
        attachments = listOf(attachment)
    )

    val draft = nylas.drafts().update(identifier = "<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>", draftId = "<NYLAS_DRAFT_ID>", requestBody = requestBody)

    println(draft)
}

data.title: Drafts
data.description: A draft of an email message. You can edit a draft until you send it as an email message.

bcc.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients to be BCC'd.

body.description: The full HTML body of the draft. Messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.
body.example: Hi, Welcome to Nylas!

cc.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients to be CC'd.

attachments.description: An array of Attachment objects, if the draft includes attachments.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

folders.description: A list of folder IDs. For Microsoft, only a single folder is supported. For Google, multiple folders may exist.

from.description: An array containing a single name/email address pair, to set as the `From` header.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response. In this case, `draft`.

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

snippet.description: A short snippet of the message body (the first 100 characters, with any HTML tags removed). This is useful for displaying a preview of a draft email message.
snippet.example: You have been invited to the following event. Welcome! WhenThu Oct 28, 2021 7am - 8am Eastern Time - Toronto Joining info

starred.description: If `true`, shows that the Draft has been starred by the user. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

subject.description: The subject line of the draft.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. If this is a new draft, the thread is empty.

to.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients.

data.body: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!
data.snippet: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!
data.subject: Hello from Nylas!

provider_error.message: Id is malformed.
Request had invalid authentication credentials. Expected OAuth 2 access token, login cookie or other valid authentication credential.

post.description: Send a draft by ID. See the [Drafts documentation](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#tag--Drafts) for more information.

parameters.name: select
parameters.description:
Specify fields that you want Nylas to return, as a comma-separated list (for example,
`select=id,updated_at`). This allows you to receive only the portion of object data that you're
interested in. You can use `select` to optimize response size and reduce latency by limiting queries
to only the information that you need.

for more information.

parent_id.description: (Microsoft and EWS only) The ID of the parent folder.

system_folder.description:
(Google only) If `true`, the folder is a standard folder created by Google. If `false`,
the folder was created by the end user.

text_color.description:
(Google only) The text color of the folder, in hexadecimal format (for example, `#0099EE`). See
the
[list of Google-defined values](https://developers.google.com/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#color)
for more information.

total_count.description: The number of items inside the folder.

unread_count.description: The number of unread items inside the folder.

attributes.description:
An array of attribute descriptors shared by system folders across providers. For example, folders
that contain sent messages ("Sent Items" on Microsoft, or "SENT" on other providers) have the
`["\\Sent"]` attribute. For more information, see
[Common folder attributes](/docs/v3/email/folders/#common-folder-attributes). If a folder does not have one of the standard system folders, Nylas returns the `attributes` array empty.

You can't query for folders using attributes, but you _can_ manually filter through folders to
find any that match the attributes you're looking for.

If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

is_inline.description: If `true`, indicates that the attachment is an inline file.

size.description: The size of the attachment, in bytes.

provider_error.message: Id is malformed.
Request had invalid authentication credentials. Expected OAuth 2 access token, login cookie or other valid authentication credential.
The mailbox is either inactive, soft-deleted, or is hosted on-premise.

error.message: Too many requests, please try again shortly.

import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.FindAttachmentQueryParams
import java.io.File

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
  val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(
      apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>"
  )

  val queryParams = FindAttachmentQueryParams("<MESSAGE_ID>")
  val attachment = nylas.attachments().download("<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>", "<ATTACHMENT_ID>", queryParams)

  File("src/main/resources/Image.png").writeBytes(attachment.bytes())
}

import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.ContactEmail
import com.nylas.models.ContactType
import com.nylas.models.CreateContactRequest
import com.nylas.models.WebPage

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
  val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>")
  val emails : List<ContactEmail> = listOf(ContactEmail("swag@nylas.com", "work"))
  val webpage : List<WebPage> = listOf(WebPage("https://www.nylas.com", "work"))

  val contactRequest = CreateContactRequest.Builder().
      emails(emails).
      companyName("Nylas").
      givenName("Nylas' Swag").
      notes("This is good swag").
      webPages(webpage).
      build()

  val contact = nylas.contacts().create("<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>", contactRequest)

  print(contact.data)
}

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: Returns the specified contacts from the address book, domain, or auto-generated contacts from email messages. EWS does _not_ support `inbox`.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: (Not supported for EWS) Returns the contacts included in the specified Contact Group.

parameters.name: recurse
parameters.description: (Microsoft Only) When `true`, returns the contacts in the specified Contact Group subgroups. The recursion goes only one level deep.

import os
import sys
from nylas import Client

nylas = Client(
    os.environ.get('NYLAS_API_KEY'),
    os.environ.get('NYLAS_API_URI')
)

)

x-code-samples.source:
import com.nylas.NylasClient
import com.nylas.models.*

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
  val nylas: NylasClient = NylasClient(apiKey = "<NYLAS_API_KEY>")

  val updateRequest = UpdateContactRequest.Builder().
      notes("This is *the best* swag").
      build()

  val contact = nylas.contacts().update("<NYLAS_GRANT_ID>", "<CONTACT_ID>", updateRequest)

  print(contact.data)
}

To calculate participant order correctly, set the metadata key `key5` to the same value on any
events you want to consider for the current set of round-robin participants. You can set this
key to any value that helps you identify events used to calculate availability in this group
(for example, `new_subscriber_onboarding`).

end_time.description:
The end of the time slot that Nylas checks availability for, in Unix epoch format.
Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

duration_minutes.description: The duration of each time slot, in minutes. Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

interval_minutes.description:
Nylas generates a time slot every `interval_minutes` (for example, every 30 minutes) and returns
only slots when all participants are free. Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

round_to.description:
Nylas rounds each time slot to the nearest `round_to` value. For example, if a time slot starts
at 9:05a.m. and `round_to` is set to `15`, Nylas rounds it to 9:15a.m. Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

account has a meeting scheduled from 10:00‚Äì11:00a.m., and you set a buffer of 30 minutes, Nylas
treats 9:30‚Äì11:30a.m. as busy.

event_ical_uid.description:
A unique ID that you can use to identify events across calendaring systems, in
[iCalendar format](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.4.7).
Recurring events might share the same ID.

Can be `null` for events synced before the year 2020.

event_id.description: The ID of the event. Generally, event IDs are unique to each user. However, Google maintains the same event ID for an event regardless of the user querying it.

organizer.description: An object that contains information about an event's organizer.

comment.description: A comment about the participant (for example, their nickname).

name.description: The participant's full name. Not all providers store participant names, so this field may be null, or an empty string.

status.description: The participant's attendance status.

event_read_only.description:
If `true`, indicates that the event is read-only. The provider sets the `read_only` value based on
the connected calendar, and you cannot modify it.

If the calendar is read-only, all events on the calendar have `read_only` set to `true`.

event_reminders.description:
A list of reminders to generate for the event. If not defined, Nylas uses the provider's default
settings.

use_default.description:
When `true`, the event uses the calendar's default reminder settings.

- **Google**: Generates a `popup`-style reminder 10 minutes before the event begins.
- **Microsoft**: Generates a reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.
- **iCloud**: Does not generate a reminder.
- **EWS**: Generates a `display`-style reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.

overrides.description:
A list of reminders for the event to use when `use_default` is `false`. If this field is empty
or omitted, and `use_default` is `false`, the event does not send reminders. If `true`, Nylas
generates both the default event reminder and any reminders in the `overrides` list.

You cannot set reminder overrides if `use_default` is `true`.

For Microsoft Graph, EWS, and iCloud, you can set only one reminder per event.

reminder_minutes.description: The number of minutes before the event to display a reminder.

reminder_method.description:
(Google and iCloud only) The method used to notify the end user about the event, with
separate options and default settings for each provider.

- **Google**:
  - Default: `popup`
  - Options: `popup`, `email`
- **iCloud**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `sound`
- **EWS**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `email`

event_recurrence.description:
An array of `RRULE` and `EXDATE` strings. Nylas includes this field only if the event is the main
(master) event. See [RFC-5545](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.5) for more details.
You can use [this tool](https://jkbrzt.github.io/rrule/) to learn more about the `RRULE` spec.

Virtual calendars don't support `DTSTART` or `TZID`.

Events inherit their timezone from the `when` object. Nylas recommends that you use the `when`
object to specify the event's start and end time.

iCloud accounts do _not_ support changing an event from recurring to non-recurring. You can create,
update, or delete information on recurring events.

ical_uid.description:
A unique ID that you can use to identify events across calendaring systems, in
[iCalendar format](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.4.7).
Recurring events might share the same ID.

Can be `null` for events synced before the year 2020.

id.description: The ID of the event. Generally, event IDs are unique to each user. However, Google maintains the same event ID for an event regardless of the user querying it.

location.description: The location of the event (for example, a physical address or the name of a meeting room).

master_event_id.description:
If the event is an instance of a recurring event series, this field contains the main (master)
event's ID.

metadata.description:
The metadata associated with the object. For more information, see
[metadata](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--metadata).

organizer.description: An object that contains information about an event's organizer.

participants.title: Participants
participants.description:
An array of participants invited to the event. The organizer doesn't need to be explicitly
included in this list.

comment.description: A comment about the participant (for example, their nickname).

name.description: The participant's full name. Not all providers store participant names, so this field may be null, or an empty string.

status.description: The participant's attendance status.

resources.description: An array of room resources added to the event.

read_only.description:
If `true`, indicates that the event is read-only. The provider sets the `read_only` value based on
the connected calendar, and you cannot modify it.

If the calendar is read-only, all events on the calendar have `read_only` set to `true`.

reminders.description:
A list of reminders to generate for the event. If not defined, Nylas uses the provider's default
settings.

use_default.description:
When `true`, the event uses the calendar's default reminder settings.

- **Google**: Generates a `popup`-style reminder 10 minutes before the event begins.
- **Microsoft**: Generates a reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.
- **iCloud**: Does not generate a reminder.
- **EWS**: Generates a `display`-style reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.

overrides.description:
A list of reminders for the event to use when `use_default` is `false`. If this field is empty
or omitted, and `use_default` is `false`, the event does not send reminders. If `true`, Nylas
generates both the default event reminder and any reminders in the `overrides` list.

You cannot set reminder overrides if `use_default` is `true`.

For Microsoft Graph, EWS, and iCloud, you can set only one reminder per event.

reminder_minutes.description: The number of minutes before the event to display a reminder.

reminder_method.description:
(Google and iCloud only) The method used to notify the end user about the event, with
separate options and default settings for each provider.

- **Google**:
  - Default: `popup`
  - Options: `popup`, `email`
- **iCloud**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `sound`
- **EWS**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `email`

recurrence.description:
An array of `RRULE` and `EXDATE` strings. Nylas includes this field only if the event is the main
(master) event. See [RFC-5545](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.5) for more details.
You can use [this tool](https://jkbrzt.github.io/rrule/) to learn more about the `RRULE` spec.

Virtual calendars don't support `DTSTART` or `TZID`.

Events inherit their timezone from the `when` object. Nylas recommends that you use the `when`
object to specify the event's start and end time.

iCloud accounts do _not_ support changing an event from recurring to non-recurring. You can create,
update, or delete information on recurring events.

status.description: (Not supported for iCloud events) The status of the event.

updated_at.description: When the event was last updated, in Unix epoch format.

visibility.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) Specifies whether the event is `public` or `private`. If not
defined, Nylas uses the account's default provider settings.

when.title: When
when.description:
An object that represents the time and duration of an event. Nylas might format `when` as one of three
sub-objects: `timespan`, `date`, or `datespan`. These sub-objects allow Nylas to capture and represent
specific points in time.

`timespan` objects include optional timezone support.

allOf.title: Timespan
allOf.description: A period of time with a specified beginning and end (for example, an hour-long lunch meeting).

start_time.description: The event's start time, in Unix epoch format.

end_time.description: The event's end time, in Unix epoch format.

start_timezone.description:
The timezone of the event's `start_time` as an
[IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones) string.

If you define `start_timezone` in your request, you must also define `end_timezone`.

end_timezone.description:
The timezone of the event's `end_time` as an
[IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones) string.

If you define `end_timezone` in your request, you must also define `start_timezone`.

allOf.title: Date
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) The date on which the event occurs, without a clock-based start
or end time (for example, a birthday or holiday).

date.description: The date of the event, in [ISO 8601 format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Calendar_dates).

allOf.title: Datespan
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) A span of days, without specific clock-based start and end times
(for example, a business quarter or semester).

event_conferencing_request.description:
An object that allows you to automatically create a conference or enter conferencing details manually.

You _cannot_ use `autocreate` and `details` in the same request.

autocreate.description:
Include `autocreate` in your request to indicate that you want Nylas to
automatically create conferencing details. If you specify the provider as `Zoom Meeting`, you must also include the `conf_grant_id` for the user creating the event.

You can include additional provider settings in `autocreate.settings`, but Nylas does _not_ validate them.

oneOf.title: Google Meet
oneOf.description: An object that contains Google Meet conferencing details.

phone.description:
The phone number associated with the Google Meet conference. This array accepts only
one phone number.

pin.description: The PIN associated with the Google Meet conference, if applicable.

url.description: The URL for the Google Meet conference.

oneOf.title: Zoom Meeting
oneOf.description: An object that contains Zoom conferencing details.

meeting_code.description: A unique ID associated with the Zoom conference.

password.description: The password for the Zoom conference, if applicable.

url.description: The URL for the Zoom conference.

oneOf.title: Microsoft Teams
oneOf.description: An object that contains Microsoft Teams conferencing details.

url.description: The URL for the Microsoft Teams conference.

comment.description: A comment about the participant (for example, their nickname).

event_reminders_create.description: A list of reminders to send for the event. If left empty or omitted, the event uses the provider defaults.

use_default.title: Use Default
use_default.description:
When `true`, the event uses the calendar's default reminder settings.

- **Google**: Generates a `popup`-style reminder 10 minutes before the event begins.
- **Microsoft**: Generates a reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.
- **iCloud**: Does not generate a reminder.
- **EWS**: Generates a `display`-style reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.

overrides.title: Overrides
overrides.description:
A list of reminders for the event to use when `use_default` is `false`. If this field is empty
or omitted, and `use_default` is `false`, the event does not send reminders. If `true`, Nylas
generates both the default event reminder and any reminders in the `overrides` list.

You cannot set reminder overrides if `use_default` is `true`.

For Microsoft Graph, EWS, and iCloud, you can set only one reminder per event.

reminder_minutes.description: The number of minutes before the event start time when a user wants to receive a reminder for this event.

reminder_method.description:
(Google and iCloud only) The method used to notify the end user about the event, with
separate options and default settings for each provider.

- **Google**:
  - Default: `popup`
  - Options: `popup`, `email`
- **iCloud**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `sound`
- **EWS**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `email`

event_time.title: Time
event_time.description: A specific point in time (for example, the start time of an event).

time.description: The time that the meeting occurs, in Unix epoch format.

timezone.description:
The timezone of the event as an
[IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones) string. If
populated, Nylas reads the value of `time` with the provided timezone.

event_when.description:

You can format `when` as one of four sub-objects: `time`, `timespan`, `date`, or `datespan`. These

allOf.title: Date
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) The date on which the event occurs, without a clock-based start
or end time (for example, a birthday or holiday).

date.description: The date of the event, in [ISO 8601 format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Calendar_dates).

allOf.title: Datespan
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) A span of days, without specific clock-based start and end times
(for example, a business quarter or semester).

busy.description:
If `true`, shows the event's time block as "busy" on shared or public calendars. This may be
called "transparency" in some systems.

capacity.description: (Not supported for EWS events) The maximum number of participants that may attend the event.

hide_participants.description: (Not supported for EWS events) When `true`, hides the event's list of participants.

resource_building.title: Resource Building
resource_building.description: The name of the building where the room is located.

resource_capacity.title: Resource Capacity
resource_capacity.description: The number of people the room can seat.

resource_email.title: Resource Email
resource_email.description: The email address associated with the room resource.

resource_floor_name.title: Resource Floor Name
resource_floor_name.description: The name of the floor where the room is located.

resource_floor_number.title: Resource Floor Number
resource_floor_number.description: The floor number where the room is located.

resource_floor_section.title: Resource Floor Section
resource_floor_section.description: The section of the floor where the room is located.

building.title: Resource Building
building.description: The name of the building where the room is located.

capacity.title: Resource Capacity
capacity.description: The number of people the room can seat.

email.title: Resource Email
email.description: The email address associated with the room resource.

floor_name.title: Resource Floor Name
floor_name.description: The name of the floor where the room is located.

floor_number.title: Resource Floor Number
floor_number.description: The floor number where the room is located.

floor_section.title: Resource Floor Section
floor_section.description: The section of the floor where the room is located.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

bcc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was BCC'd to. For received messages, this is nearly always empty.

body.description: The full HTML message body. Email messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.
body.example: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!

cc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was CC'd to.

date.description: Unix timestamp that represents when _the mail server_ received the email message. This may be different from the unified `Date` header in a raw Message object.

attachments.description: An array of Attachment objects, if the email message includes attachments.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) that the email message appears in. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

from.description: A list of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent from. This is usually one pair only, but can be many.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response (in this case, `message`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

schedule_id.description: The ID of the scheduled email message. Nylas returns the `schedule_id` if `send_at` is set.

snippet.description: A short snippet (the first 100 characters, with HTML tags removed) of the email message body. This is useful for displaying a preview of the message.

bcc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was BCC'd to. For received messages, this is nearly always empty.

body.description: The full HTML message body. Email messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.
body.example: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!

cc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was CC'd to.

date.description: Unix timestamp that represents when _the mail server_ received the email message. This may be different from the unified `Date` header in a raw Message object.

attachments.description: An array of Attachment objects, if the email message includes attachments.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) that the email message appears in. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

from.description: A list of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent from. This is usually one pair only, but can be many.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response (in this case, `message`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

subject.description: The subject of the email message.

epoch format.

The date when the most recent incoming email message in the thread was received, in Unix epoch

subject.description: The subject line of the thread.

unread.description: When `false`, indicates that all email messages in the thread have been read.

Microsoft email messages can only be in one folder at a time.

Google email messages can be in multiple folders.

draft.title: Drafts

body.description: The full HTML body of the draft. Messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.

attributes.description:
An array of attribute descriptors shared by system folders across providers. For example, folders
that contain sent messages ("Sent Items" on Microsoft, or "SENT" on other providers) have the
`["\\Sent"]` attribute. For more information, see
[Common folder attributes](/docs/v3/email/folders/#common-folder-attributes). If a folder does not have one of the standard system folders, Nylas returns the `attributes` array empty.

You can't query for folders using attributes, but you _can_ manually filter through folders to
find any that match the attributes you're looking for.
