description.description: (Not supported for iCloud or EWS) A brief description of the calendar.

location.description: (Not supported for iCloud or EWS) The geographic location of the calendar, as free-form text.

metadata.description:
The metadata associated with the object. For more information, see
[metadata](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--metadata).

timezone.description:
(Google and virtual calendars only) An [IANA timezone database](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz_database)
formatted string (for example, `America/New_York`).

description.description: (Not supported for iCloud or EWS) A brief description of the calendar.

hex_color.description:
(Not supported for iCloud or EWS) The background color of the calendar, in hexadecimal format (for
example, `#0099EE`). When empty, Nylas uses the default background color.

You can set or modify this value using a `PUT` request only.

hex_foreground_color.description:
(Google only) The foreground color of the calendar, in hexadecimal format (for example, `#0099EE`).
When empty, Nylas uses the default foreground color.

You can modify this value using a `PUT` request only.

location.description: (Not supported for iCloud or EWS) The geographic location of the calendar, as free-form text.

metadata.description:
The metadata associated with the object. For more information, see
[metadata](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--metadata).

name.description:
The name of the calendar.

Microsoft doesn't allow you to update the name of an end user's primary calendar.

timezone.description:
(Google and virtual calendars only) An [IANA timezone database](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz_database)
formatted string (for example, `America/New_York`).

participants.description: A list of participants that you want to get availability information for.

calendar_ids.description:
A list of calendar IDs associated with each participant's email address. If empty, Nylas
uses the participant's primary calendar ID.

open_hours.description:
An array of the participant's open hours. Nylas searches for free time slots within these
open hours.

days.description:
The days of the week that the open hours settings are applied to. Sunday corresponds to `0`, and
Saturday corresponds to `6`.

timezone.description: The calendar's time zone as an [IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz_database) string.

start.description:
The start time for the open hours settings, in 24-hour time format. Nylas omits leading zeroes.

The minimum start time is `0:00`, and the maximum is `23:49`.

end.description: The end time for the open hours settings, in 24-hour time format. Nylas omits leading zeroes.

exdates.description: A list of dates that Nylas excludes from the account's open hours, in `YYYY-MM-DD` format.

start_time.description:
The beginning of the time slot that Nylas checks availability for, in Unix epoch format.
Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

end_time.description:
The end of the time slot that Nylas checks availability for, in Unix epoch format.
Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

duration_minutes.description: The duration of each time slot, in minutes. Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

interval_minutes.description:
Nylas generates a time slot every `interval_minutes` (for example, every 30 minutes) and returns
only slots when all participants are free. Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

round_to.description:
Nylas rounds each time slot to the nearest `round_to` value. For example, if a time slot starts
at 9:05a.m. and `round_to` is set to `15`, Nylas rounds it to 9:15a.m. Must be a multiple of 5 minutes.

buffer.description:
The amount of buffer time Nylas adds around existing meetings, in minutes. For example, if an
account has a meeting scheduled from 10:00‚Äì11:00a.m., and you set a buffer of 30 minutes, Nylas
treats 9:30‚Äì11:30a.m. as busy.
buffer.title: buffer

before.description:
The amount of buffer time to add before meetings, in increments of five minutes. For example,
if an account has a meeting scheduled from 10:00‚Äì11:00a.m., and you set a `before` buffer of
30 minutes, Nylas treats 9:30‚Äì11:00a.m. as busy.

This value must be between 0 and 120, and must be divisible by 5.

after.description:
The amount of buffer time to add after meetings, in increments of five minutes. For example, if
an account has a meeting scheduled from 10:00‚Äì11:00a.m., and you set an `after` buffer of 15
minutes, Nylas treats 10:00‚Äì11:15a.m. as busy.

This value must be between 0 and 120, and must be divisible by 5.

default_open_hours.description:
A default set of open hours to apply to all participants. You can overwrite these open hours for
individual participants by specifying `open_hours` on the Participant object.

days.description:
The days of the week that the open hours settings are applied to. Sunday corresponds to `0`, and
Saturday corresponds to `6`.

timezone.description: The calendar's time zone as an [IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz_database) string.

start.description:
The start time for the open hours settings, in 24-hour time format. Nylas omits leading zeroes.

The minimum start time is `0:00`, and the maximum is `23:49`.

end.description: The end time for the open hours settings, in 24-hour time format. Nylas omits leading zeroes.

exdates.description: A list of dates that Nylas excludes from the account's open hours, in `YYYY-MM-DD` format.

round_robin_group_id.description:
The ID on events that Nylas considers when calculating the order of round-robin participants.
This is used for both max-fairness and max-availability calculations.

To calculate participant order correctly, set the metadata key `key5` to the same value on any
events you want to consider for the current set of round-robin participants. You can set this
key to any value that helps you identify events used to calculate availability in this group
(for example, `new_subscriber_onboarding`).

start_time.description:
The start of a time block, in Unix epoch format. Nylas uses `start_time` and `end_time` to assess
the specified account's free/busy schedule.

end_time.description:
The end of a time block, in Unix epoch format. Nylas uses `start_time` and `end_time` to assess
the specified account's free/busy schedule.

Nylas can query a timespan of up to 30 days from the `start_time`.

emails.description: A list of email addresses to check the free/busy schedules for.

busy.description:
If `true`, shows the event's time block as "busy" on shared or public calendars. This may be
called "transparency" in some systems.

capacity.description: (Not supported for EWS events) The maximum number of participants that may attend the event.

conferencing.description:
An object that allows you to automatically create a conference or enter conferencing details manually.

You _cannot_ use `autocreate` and `details` in the same request.

autocreate.description:
Include `autocreate` in your request to indicate that you want Nylas to
automatically create conferencing details. If you specify the provider as `Zoom Meeting`, you must also include the `conf_grant_id` for the user creating the event.

You can include additional provider settings in `autocreate.settings`, but Nylas does _not_ validate them.

oneOf.title: Google Meet
oneOf.description: An object that contains Google Meet conferencing details.

phone.description:
The phone number associated with the Google Meet conference. This array accepts only
one phone number.

pin.description: The PIN associated with the Google Meet conference, if applicable.

url.description: The URL for the Google Meet conference.

oneOf.title: Zoom Meeting
oneOf.description: An object that contains Zoom conferencing details.

meeting_code.description: A unique ID associated with the Zoom conference.

password.description: The password for the Zoom conference, if applicable.

url.description: The URL for the Zoom conference.

oneOf.title: Microsoft Teams
oneOf.description: An object that contains Microsoft Teams conferencing details.

url.description: The URL for the Microsoft Teams conference.

description.description: A brief description of the event (for example, its agenda). The description might be returned as an HTML string depending on how the provider formats it.

hide_participants.description: (Not supported for EWS events) When `true`, hides the event's list of participants.

location.description: The location of the event (for example, a physical address or the name of a meeting room).

metadata.description:
The metadata associated with the object. For more information, see
[metadata](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--metadata).

comment.description: A comment about the participant (for example, their nickname).

recurrence.description:
An array of `RRULE` and `EXDATE` strings. Nylas includes this field only if the event is the main
(master) event. See [RFC-5545](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.5) for more details.
You can use [this tool](https://jkbrzt.github.io/rrule/) to learn more about the `RRULE` spec.

Virtual calendars don't support `DTSTART` or `TZID`.

Events inherit their timezone from the `when` object. Nylas recommends that you use the `when`
object to specify the event's start and end time.

iCloud accounts do _not_ support changing an event from recurring to non-recurring. You can create,
update, or delete information on recurring events.

reminders.description: A list of reminders to send for the event. If left empty or omitted, the event uses the provider defaults.

use_default.title: Use Default
use_default.description:
When `true`, the event uses the calendar's default reminder settings.

- **Google**: Generates a `popup`-style reminder 10 minutes before the event begins.
- **Microsoft**: Generates a reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.
- **iCloud**: Does not generate a reminder.
- **EWS**: Generates a `display`-style reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.

overrides.title: Overrides
overrides.description:
A list of reminders for the event to use when `use_default` is `false`. If this field is empty
or omitted, and `use_default` is `false`, the event does not send reminders. If `true`, Nylas
generates both the default event reminder and any reminders in the `overrides` list.

You cannot set reminder overrides if `use_default` is `true`.

For Microsoft Graph, EWS, and iCloud, you can set only one reminder per event.

reminder_minutes.description: The number of minutes before the event start time when a user wants to receive a reminder for this event.

reminder_method.description:
(Google and iCloud only) The method used to notify the end user about the event, with
separate options and default settings for each provider.

- **Google**:
  - Default: `popup`
  - Options: `popup`, `email`
- **iCloud**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `sound`
- **EWS**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `email`

visibility.description: The event's visibility. If not defined, Nylas uses the calendar's default settings.

when.title: When
when.description:
An object that represents the time and duration of an event.

You can format `when` as one of four sub-objects: `time`, `timespan`, `date`, or `datespan`. These
sub-objects allow you to capture and represent specific points in time.

`time` and `timespan` objects include optional timezone support.

allOf.title: Time
allOf.description: A specific point in time (for example, the start time of an event).

time.description: The time that the meeting occurs, in Unix epoch format.

timezone.description:
The timezone of the event as an
[IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones) string. If
populated, Nylas reads the value of `time` with the provided timezone.

allOf.title: Timespan
allOf.description: A period of time with a specified beginning and end (for example, an hour-long lunch meeting).

start_time.description: The event's start time, in Unix epoch format.

end_time.description: The event's end time, in Unix epoch format.

start_timezone.description:
The timezone of the event's `start_time` as an
[IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones) string.

If you define `start_timezone` in your request, you must also define `end_timezone`.

end_timezone.description:
The timezone of the event's `end_time` as an
[IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones) string.

If you define `end_timezone` in your request, you must also define `start_timezone`.

allOf.title: Date
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) The date on which the event occurs, without a clock-based start
or end time (for example, a birthday or holiday).

date.description: The date of the event, in [ISO 8601 format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Calendar_dates).

allOf.title: Datespan
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) A span of days, without specific clock-based start and end times
(for example, a business quarter or semester).

busy.description:
If `true`, shows the event's time block as "busy" on shared or public calendars. This might be
called "transparency" in some systems.

capacity.description: The maximum number of participants that may attend the event.

conferencing.description:
An object that allows you to automatically create a conference or enter conferencing details manually.

You _cannot_ use `autocreate` and `details` in the same request.

autocreate.description:
Include `autocreate` in your request to indicate that you want Nylas to
automatically create conferencing details. If you specify the provider as `Zoom Meeting`, you must also include the `conf_grant_id` for the user creating the event.

You can include additional provider settings in `autocreate.settings`, but Nylas does _not_ validate them.

phone.description:
The phone number associated with the Google Meet conference. This array accepts only

pin.description: The PIN associated with the Google Meet conference, if applicable.

url.description: The URL for the Google Meet conference.

url.description: The URL for the Zoom conference.

location.description: The location of the event (for example, a physical address or the name of a meeting room).

metadata.description:
The metadata associated with the object. For more information, see
[metadata](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--metadata).

comment.description: A comment about the participant (for example, their nickname).

An array of `RRULE` and `EXDATE` strings. Nylas includes this field only if the event is the main

Events inherit their timezone from the `when` object. Nylas recommends that you use the `when`
object to specify the event's start and end time.

iCloud accounts do _not_ support changing an event from recurring to non-recurring. You can create,
update, or delete information on recurring events.

reminders.description:
A list of reminders to generate for the event. If not defined, Nylas uses the provider's default
settings.

use_default.description:
When `true`, the event uses the calendar's default reminder settings.

- **Google**: Generates a `popup`-style reminder 10 minutes before the event begins.
- **Microsoft**: Generates a reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.
- **iCloud**: Does not generate a reminder.
- **EWS**: Generates a `display`-style reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.

overrides.description:
A list of reminders for the event to use when `use_default` is `false`. If this field is empty
or omitted, and `use_default` is `false`, the event does not send reminders. If `true`, Nylas
generates both the default event reminder and any reminders in the `overrides` list.

You cannot set reminder overrides if `use_default` is `true`.

For Microsoft Graph, EWS, and iCloud, you can set only one reminder per event.

reminder_minutes.description: The number of minutes before the event to display a reminder.

reminder_method.description:
(Google and iCloud only) The method used to notify the end user about the event, with
separate options and default settings for each provider.

- **Google**:
  - Default: `popup`
  - Options: `popup`, `email`
- **iCloud**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `sound`
- **EWS**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `email`

when.description:
An object that represents the time and duration of an event.

You can format `when` as one of four sub-objects: `time`, `timespan`, `date`, or `datespan`. These
sub-objects allow you to capture and represent specific points in time.

`time` and `timespan` objects include optional timezone support.

time.description: The time that the meeting occurs, in Unix epoch format.

allOf.description: A period of time with a specified beginning and end (for example, an hour-long lunch meeting).

start_time.description: The event's start time, in Unix epoch format.

end_time.description: The event's end time, in Unix epoch format.

start_timezone.description:

allOf.title: Date
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) The date on which the event occurs, without a clock-based start
or end time (for example, a birthday or holiday).

date.description: The date of the event, in [ISO 8601 format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Calendar_dates).

allOf.title: Datespan
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) A span of days, without specific clock-based start and end times
(for example, a business quarter or semester).

status.description: A participant's RSVP status for the event.

starred.description: Set to `true` to mark as starred; `false` to mark as not starred.

unread.description: Set to `true` to mark as unread; `false` to mark as read.

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) to apply, overwriting all folders previously associated with the message. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

message_id.description: IDs of the email messages to clean.

ignore_links.description: If `true`, removes link-related tags (`<a>`) from the email message while keeping the text.

ignore_images.description: If `true`, removes images from the email message.

images_as_markdown.description: If `true`, converts images in the email message to Markdown.

ignore_tables.description: If `true`, removes table-related tags (`<table>`, `<th>`, `<td>`, `<tr>`) from the email message while keeping rows.

remove_conclusion_phrases.description: If `true`, removes phrases such as "Best" and "Regards" in the email message signature.

send_at.description: The time when the email message will be sent, in Unix epoch format. This time must be at least 1 minute in the future from the time you make the request. You can schedule sending up to 30 days in the future.

reply_to_message_id.description: The ID of the email message that you're replying to. For Gmail and Microsoft Graph, this is the provider ID for the email message that you're replying to. For IMAP Send, this is the RFC822 `Message-ID` header of the email message that you're replying to.

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

content.description: Must be Base64-encoded if you're using the `application/json` schema. Use binary format if you're using `multipart/form-data`. For more information, see [Working with email attachments](/docs/v3/email/attachments/#attachment-schemas-and-size-limits).

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

custom_headers.description: An array of custom headers to add to the email message.

value.subject: Interview Confirmation
value.body: "Thanks for your interest in Nylas v3! This email contains a tracking pixel."

value.subject: This Message Has an Inline Image
value.body: This email has an inline image using an attachment id:

send_at.description: The time when the email message will be sent, in Unix epoch format.

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

custom_headers.description: An array of custom headers to add to the email message.

attachment.description: The content of the attachment (if available), in binary format.

prompt.title: Prompt
prompt.description: The prompt that Smart Compose uses to generate a message suggestion.
prompt.example: Reply to John Doe about the upcoming project.

starred.description: When `true`, indicates that the thread is starred.

unread.description: When `false`, indicates that all email messages in the thread have been read.

folders.description:
The IDs of the folders to apply to the thread. This overwrites all previously assigned
folders for all email messages in the thread.

schema.title: Drafts
schema.description: A draft of an email message. You can edit a draft until you send it as an email message.

bcc.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients to be BCC'd.

body.description: The full HTML body of the draft. Messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.
body.example: Hi, Welcome to Nylas!

cc.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients to be CC'd.

attachments.description: An array of file attachments to include in the draft. You can use either the `application/json` or `multipart/form-data` schema, depending on attachment size. The `application/json` format is limited to 3MB including the message body, and the `content` must be Base64 encoded. The `multipart/form-data` format size is limited by the provider to 25MB.  See [Attachments](/#tag--Attachments) for more information.

content.description: Must be Base64-encoded if using the `application/json` schema. Use binary format if using `multipart/form-data`.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``). Only include a value for this field if the attachment is inline."

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message. This is used to set an alternative `Reply-To` header in the sent email message. Not all providers support setting this in a Draft.

reply_to_message_id.description: The unique identifier of the message to which you want to draft a reply.

starred.description: If `true`, the draft is starred.

subject.description: The subject line of the draft.

to.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients.

custom_headers.description: An array of custom headers to add to the message.

draft.description: A draft of an email message. You can edit a draft until you send it as an email message.

bcc.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients to be BCC'd.

starred.description: If `true`, the draft is starred.

subject.description: The subject line of the draft.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. If you're creating a new draft, leave this empty.

to.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients.

custom_headers.description: An array of custom headers to add to the email message.

attachment.description: The content of the attachment, in binary format.

name.description: Creates a folder with the specified display name.

parent_id.description: (Microsoft and EWS only) The ID of the parent folder.

text_color.description: (Google only) The text color of the folder, in hexadecimal format (for example, `#0099EE`). See the [list of Google-defined values](https://developers.google.com/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#color) for more information.

background_color.description: (Google only) The background color of the folder, in hexadecimal format (for example, `#0099EE`). See the [list of Google-defined values](https://developers.google.com/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#color) for more information.

company_name.title: Contact Company Name
company_name.description: The name of the company that the contact is affiliated with (for example, their workplace).

items.title: Contact Email
items.description: An array of the contact's email addresses. EWS supports up to three email addresses.

items.title: Contact Group ID
items.description: A list of IDs for contact groups the contact is included in.

items.title: Contact IM Address

type.description: The protocol for the IM address.

items.description: An array of the contact's instant messaging (IM) addresses.

job_title.title: Contact Job Title
job_title.description: The contact's occupation or job title.

manager_name.title: Contact Manager Name
manager_name.description: The name of the contact's manager.

nickname.title: Contact Nickname
nickname.description: A custom nickname for the contact.

notes.title: Contact Notes
notes.description: Notes about with the contact (for example, their favorite food).

office_location.title: Contact Office Location
office_location.description: The location of the office where the contact works.

items.title: Contact Phone Number

number.description: The contact's phone number, including its [country code](https://www.itu.int/oth/T0202.aspx?parent=T0202).

items.description: An array of phone numbers associated with the contact.

items.title: Contact Physical Address

street_address.description: The street address of a location associated with the contact (for example, their work).

postal_code.description: The postal code of a location associated with the contact.

state.description: The state or province in which the contact is located.

country.description: The country in which the contact is located.

city.description: The town or city in which the contact is located.

items.description: An array of physical addresses associated with the contact.

suffix.title: Contact Suffix
suffix.description: (Not supported for EWS) The suffix of a contact's name, if applicable.

items.title: Contact Web Page

url.description: A URL that links to the contact's website.

items.description: An array of the contact's websites. EWS supports only one `work` website per contact.

ACCESS_TOKEN.description:
The Nylas **access token** for a specific grant. Issued as part of OAuth 2.1 flow token
exchange.

NYLAS_API_KEY.description:
The Nylas **API key** provides application-level access to APIs and all grants. You can
generate these from the v3 Dashboard. Learn more about
[authorizing requests in Nylas v3](/docs/v3/auth/).

bcc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was BCC'd to. For received messages, this is nearly always empty.

body.description: The full HTML message body. Email messages with only plain-text representations are up-converted to HTML.
body.example: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!

cc.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was CC'd to.

date.description: Unix timestamp that represents when _the mail server_ received the email message. This may be different from the unified `Date` header in a raw Message object.

attachments.description: An array of Attachment objects, if the email message includes attachments.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

folders.description: The ID(s) of the folder(s) that the email message appears in. Microsoft messages can be in a single folder only. Google allows a single message to appear in multiple folders.

from.description: A list of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent from. This is usually one pair only, but can be many.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response (in this case, `message`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

schedule_id.description: The ID of the scheduled email message. Nylas returns the `schedule_id` if `send_at` is set.

snippet.description: A short snippet (the first 100 characters, with HTML tags removed) of the email message body. This is useful for displaying a preview of the message.
snippet.example: You have been invited to the following event. Welcome! WhenThu Oct 28, 2021 7am - 8am Eastern Time - Toronto Joining info

starred.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been starred by the user. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

subject.description: The subject of the email message.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. Every email message is associated with a thread, whether that thread contains only one message or many. If this is a new email message, Nylas assigns a `thread_id` to it.

to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent to.

unread.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been read by the user.

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

time_slots.description: An array of busy time slots.

end_time.description: The end of a time slot, in Unix epoch format.

status.description: The status of the time slot.

object.description: The object type (in this case, always `time_slot`).

error.description:

a description of the error.

object.description:

busy.description:
If `true`, shows the event's time block as `busy` on shared or public calendars. This may be
called "transparency" in some systems.

calendar_id.description: The calendar ID associated with the event.

conferencing.description: An object that contains event conferencing details. Nylas also appends the conference details to the Event description.

autocreate.description: The autocreate settings you specififed for the meeting, plus the details created by the conferencing provider. The autocreated conference details are also appended to the Event description.

oneOf.title: Google Meet
oneOf.description: An object that contains Google Meet conferencing details.

phone.description: The phone number associated with the Google Meet conference.

pin.description: The PIN associated with the Google Meet conference, if applicable.

url.description: The URL for the Google Meet conference.

oneOf.title: Zoom Meeting
oneOf.description: An object that contains Zoom conferencing details.

meeting_code.description: A unique ID associated with the Zoom conference.

password.description: The password for the Zoom conference, if applicable.

url.description: The URL for the Zoom conference.

oneOf.title: Microsoft Teams
oneOf.description: An object that contains Microsoft Teams conferencing details.

url.description: The URL for the Microsoft Teams conference.

created_at.description: When the event was created, in Unix epoch format.

description.description: A brief description of the event (for example, its agenda). The description might be returned as an HTML string depending on how the provider formats it.
description.example: Time for us to sync weekly on any new project changes

hide_participants.description: (Not supported for iCloud or EWS events) When `true`, hides the event's list of participants.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

html_link.description: (Not supported for EWS events) A link to the event on the provider.

ical_uid.description:
A unique ID that you can use to identify events across calendaring systems, in
[iCalendar format](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.4.7).
Recurring events might share the same ID.

Can be `null` for events synced before the year 2020.

id.description: The ID of the event. Generally, event IDs are unique to each user. However, Google maintains the same event ID for an event regardless of the user querying it.

location.description: The location of the event (for example, a physical address or the name of a meeting room).

master_event_id.description:
If the event is an instance of a recurring event series, this field contains the main (master)
event's ID.

metadata.description:
The metadata associated with the object. For more information, see
[metadata](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--metadata).

organizer.description: An object that contains information about an event's organizer.

participants.title: Participants
participants.description:
An array of participants invited to the event. The organizer doesn't need to be explicitly
included in this list.

comment.description: A comment about the participant (for example, their nickname).

name.description: The participant's full name. Not all providers store participant names, so this field may be null, or an empty string.

status.description: The participant's attendance status.

resources.description: An array of room resources added to the event.

read_only.description:
If `true`, indicates that the event is read-only. The provider sets the `read_only` value based on
the connected calendar, and you cannot modify it.

If the calendar is read-only, all events on the calendar have `read_only` set to `true`.

reminders.description:
A list of reminders to generate for the event. If not defined, Nylas uses the provider's default
settings.

use_default.description:
When `true`, the event uses the calendar's default reminder settings.

- **Google**: Generates a `popup`-style reminder 10 minutes before the event begins.
- **Microsoft**: Generates a reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.
- **iCloud**: Does not generate a reminder.
- **EWS**: Generates a `display`-style reminder 15 minutes before the event begins.

overrides.description:
A list of reminders for the event to use when `use_default` is `false`. If this field is empty
or omitted, and `use_default` is `false`, the event does not send reminders. If `true`, Nylas
generates both the default event reminder and any reminders in the `overrides` list.

You cannot set reminder overrides if `use_default` is `true`.

For Microsoft Graph, EWS, and iCloud, you can set only one reminder per event.

reminder_minutes.description: The number of minutes before the event to display a reminder.

reminder_method.description:
(Google and iCloud only) The method used to notify the end user about the event, with
separate options and default settings for each provider.

- **Google**:
  - Default: `popup`
  - Options: `popup`, `email`
- **iCloud**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `sound`
- **EWS**:
  - Default: `display`
  - Options: `display`, `email`

recurrence.description:
An array of `RRULE` and `EXDATE` strings. Nylas includes this field only if the event is the main
(master) event. See [RFC-5545](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.5) for more details.
You can use [this tool](https://jkbrzt.github.io/rrule/) to learn more about the `RRULE` spec.

Virtual calendars don't support `DTSTART` or `TZID`.

Events inherit their timezone from the `when` object. Nylas recommends that you use the `when`
object to specify the event's start and end time.

iCloud accounts do _not_ support changing an event from recurring to non-recurring. You can create,
update, or delete information on recurring events.

status.description: (Not supported for iCloud events) The status of the event.

updated_at.description: When the event was last updated, in Unix epoch format.

visibility.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) Specifies whether the event is `public` or `private`. If not
defined, Nylas uses the account's default provider settings.

when.title: When
when.description:
An object that represents the time and duration of an event. Nylas might format `when` as one of three
sub-objects: `timespan`, `date`, or `datespan`. These sub-objects allow Nylas to capture and represent
specific points in time.

`timespan` objects include optional timezone support.

allOf.title: Timespan
allOf.description: A period of time with a specified beginning and end (for example, an hour-long lunch meeting).

start_time.description: The event's start time, in Unix epoch format.

end_time.description: The event's end time, in Unix epoch format.

start_timezone.description:
The timezone of the event's `start_time` as an
[IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones) string.

If you define `start_timezone` in your request, you must also define `end_timezone`.

end_timezone.description:
The timezone of the event's `end_time` as an
[IANA-formatted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones) string.

If you define `end_timezone` in your request, you must also define `start_timezone`.

allOf.title: Date
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) The date on which the event occurs, without a clock-based start
or end time (for example, a birthday or holiday).

date.description: The date of the event, in [ISO 8601 format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Calendar_dates).

allOf.title: Datespan
allOf.description:
(Not supported for iCloud events) A span of days, without specific clock-based start and end times
(for example, a business quarter or semester).

busy.description:
If `true`, shows the event's time block as `busy` on shared or public calendars. This may be
called "transparency" in some systems.

calendar_id.description: The calendar ID associated with the event.

conferencing.description: An object that contains event conferencing details. Nylas also appends the conference details to the Event description.

autocreate.description: The autocreate settings you specififed for the meeting, plus the details created by the conferencing provider. The autocreated conference details are also appended to the Event description.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

object.description: The object type of the response (in this case, `message`).

reply_to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that should receive replies to the email message.

schedule_id.description: The ID of the scheduled email message. Nylas returns the `schedule_id` if `send_at` is set.

snippet.description: A short snippet (the first 100 characters, with HTML tags removed) of the email message body. This is useful for displaying a preview of the message.
snippet.example: You have been invited to the following event. Welcome! WhenThu Oct 28, 2021 7am - 8am Eastern Time - Toronto Joining info

starred.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been starred by the user. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

subject.description: The subject of the email message.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. Every email message is associated with a thread, whether that thread contains only one message or many. If this is a new email message, Nylas assigns a `thread_id` to it.

to.description: An array of name/email address pairs that the email message was sent to.

unread.description: If `true`, shows that the email message has been read by the user.

use_draft.description:
(Google and Microsoft only) If `true` when scheduling a message, Nylas saves the email message in
the end user's Drafts folder until it's sent. For more information, see
[Schedule email messages to send in the future](/docs/v3/email/scheduled-send/). The default `false`
will be used if this field is omitted.

smart_compose_200.description: Returns a suggestion for a message

data.suggestion:
Dear John,

I hope this email finds you well. I wanted to reach out and inform you about an exciting upcoming project that we will be working on together. This project has the potential to be a game-changer for our company, and I believe your expertise and skills will be invaluable to its success. I look forward to discussing the project with you further and hearing your input and ideas. Let's make this project a resounding success!

Best regards,
[Your Name]

snippet.example: You have been invited to the following event. Welcome! WhenThu Oct 28, 2021 7am - 8am Eastern Time - Toronto Joining info

starred.description: If `true`, shows that the Draft has been starred by the user. For EWS, this is only supported for Microsoft Exchange 2010 or later.

subject.description: The subject line of the draft.

thread_id.description: A reference to the parent Thread object. If this is a new draft, the thread is empty.

to.description: The name/email address pairs of the recipients.

data.body: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!
data.snippet: Hello, I just sent a message using Nylas!
data.subject: Hello from Nylas!

folders.description: Returned all folders

next_cursor.description: The next cursor for the request.

background_color.description:
(Google only) The background color of the folder, in hexadecimal format (for example, `#0099EE`).
See the
[list of Google-defined values](https://developers.google.com/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#color)
for more information.

child_count.description: (Microsoft and EWS only) The number of immediate child folders nested under the specified folder.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

parent_id.description: (Microsoft and EWS only) The ID of the parent folder.

system_folder.description:
(Google only) If `true`, the folder is a standard folder created by Google. If `false`,
the folder was created by the end user.

text_color.description:
(Google only) The text color of the folder, in hexadecimal format (for example, `#0099EE`). See
the
[list of Google-defined values](https://developers.google.com/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#color)
for more information.

total_count.description: The number of items inside the folder.

unread_count.description: The number of unread items inside the folder.

attributes.description:
An array of attribute descriptors shared by system folders across providers. For example, folders
that contain sent messages ("Sent Items" on Microsoft, or "SENT" on other providers) have the
`["\\Sent"]` attribute. For more information, see
[Common folder attributes](/docs/v3/email/folders/#common-folder-attributes). If a folder does not have one of the standard system folders, Nylas returns the `attributes` array empty.

You can't query for folders using attributes, but you _can_ manually filter through folders to
find any that match the attributes you're looking for.

background_color.description:
(Google only) The background color of the folder, in hexadecimal format (for example, `#0099EE`).
See the
[list of Google-defined values](https://developers.google.com/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#color)
for more information.

child_count.description: (Microsoft and EWS only) The number of immediate child folders nested under the specified folder.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

parent_id.description: (Microsoft and EWS only) The ID of the parent folder.

system_folder.description:

the folder was created by the end user.

text_color.description:

the
[list of Google-defined values](https://developers.google.com/gmail/api/reference/rest/v1/users.labels#color)
for more information.

total_count.description: The number of items inside the folder.

unread_count.description: The number of unread items inside the folder.

attributes.description:
An array of attribute descriptors shared by system folders across providers. For example, folders
that contain sent messages ("Sent Items" on Microsoft, or "SENT" on other providers) have the
`["\\Sent"]` attribute. For more information, see
[Common folder attributes](/docs/v3/email/folders/#common-folder-attributes). If a folder does not have one of the standard system folders, Nylas returns the `attributes` array empty.

You can't query for folders using attributes, but you _can_ manually filter through folders to
find any that match the attributes you're looking for.

content_type.description: The [MIME type](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Basics_of_HTTP/MIME_types/Common_types) of the attachment, used by the email client to determine how to display the attachment. If you don't provide a type, Nylas infers it from the file name. The value of this field is exactly the same as the email attachment's `Content-Type` header. The provider might set additional parameters, such as `name` and `charset`.

filename.description: The file name of the attachment.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

content_id.description: (Inline attachments only) The alphanumeric `cid` from the `` tag in the email message's HTML. For example, you might see something like `` in the message body. Sometimes, the `content_id` value is contained in angle brackets (for example, ``).

content_disposition.description: (Not supported for Microsoft and EWS) The content disposition of the attachment. Usually, this is `inline` or `attachment` followed by the file name (for example, `inline; filename="some-image.jpeg"`).

is_inline.description: If `true`, indicates that the attachment is an inline file.

size.description: The size of the attachment, in bytes.

attachment_file.description: The attached file as a binary stream (`application/octect-stream`). Use the [Return Attachment Info endpoint](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#get-/v3/grants/-grant_id-/attachments/-attachment_id-) if you need to find the attachment's MIME type.

next_cursor.description: The next cursor for the request.

next_cursor.description: The next cursor for the request.

grant_id.description: The ID of the end user's grant.

limit.name: limit
limit.description: The maximum number of objects to return. See [pagination](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--pagination) for more information.

page_token.name: page_token
page_token.description: An identifier that specifies which page of data to return. You can get this value from the `next_cursor` response field. See [Pagination](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--pagination) for more information.

metadata_pair.name: metadata_pair
metadata_pair.description: Pass a metadata key/value pair (for example, `?metadata_pair=key1:value`) to search for metadata associated with objects. See [Metadata](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--metadata) for more information.

field_selection.name: select
field_selection.description:
Specify fields that you want Nylas to return, as a comma-separated list (for example,
`select=id,updated_at`). This allows you to receive only the portion of object data that you're
interested in. You can use `select` to optimize response size and reduce latency by limiting queries
to only the information that you need.

calendar_id.name: calendar_id
calendar_id.description:
Filter for the specified calendar ID.

(Not supported for iCloud) You can use `primary` to query the end user's primary calendar.

show_cancelled.name: show_cancelled
show_cancelled.description:
(Not supported for iCloud or EWS) If `true`, Nylas filters for events whose `status` is `cancelled`.
Nylas returns recurring events regardless of the value of `show_cancelled`.

Different providers have different semantics for cancelled events:

- **Google**: An event is considered cancelled after an end user deletes it from their calendar,
until it is eventually hard-deleted and is no longer readable.
- **Microsoft**: An event is considered cancelled if the end user is invited to an event and the
organizer deletes it. The cancelled version of the event stays on the participants' calendars until
they delete it manually.

title.name: title
title.description: Filter for events that match the specified title. The filter is case insensitive and will match partial titles.

description.name: description
description.description: Filter for events matching the specified description. The filter is case insensitive and will match partial descriptions.

ical_uid.name: ical_uid
ical_uid.description:
(Not supported for iCloud) Filter for events with the specified `ical_uid`. You _cannot_ apply other
filters if you use this parameter.

location.name: location
location.description: Filter for events with the specified location. The filter is case insensitive and will match partial locations.

start.name: start
start.description:
Filter for events that start at or before the specified time, in Unix epoch format. For example, if
you filter for events that start at 9:00a.m., and the calendar includes an event that runs from
8:30‚Äì9:30a.m., Nylas returns that event.

Defaults to the time that you make the request.

The `start` value cannot be later than `end`. For iCloud accounts, the difference between `start`
and `end` can't be greater than six months.

end.name: end
end.description:
Filter for events that end at or before the specified time, in Unix epoch format. For example, if
you filter for events that end at 5:00p.m., and the calendar includes an event that runs from
4:30‚Äì5:30p.m., Nylas returns that event.

Defaults to one month from the time you make the request.

The `end` value cannot be earlier than `start`. For iCloud accounts, the difference between `start`
and `end` can't be greater than six months.

master_event_id.name: master_event_id
master_event_id.description:
(Not supported for iCloud) Filter for instances of recurring events with the specified `master_event_id`.

`master_event_id` is _not_ respected by metadata filtering.

busy.name: busy
busy.description: (Not supported for iCloud) Filter for events with the specified `busy` status.

updated_before.name: updated_before
updated_before.description:
(Google, Microsoft, and EWS only) Filter for events that have been updated before the specified time,
in Unix epoch format.

`updated_before` is _not_ respected by metadata filtering.

updated_after.name: updated_after
updated_after.description:
(Google, Microsoft, and EWS only) Filter for events that have been updated after the specified time,
in Unix epoch format.

`updated_after` is _not_ respected by metadata filtering.

attendees.name: attendees
attendees.description:
(Not supported for virtual calendars) Filter for events that include the specified attendees. This
parameter accepts a comma-delimited list of email addresses.

event_type.name: event_type
event_type.description:
(Google only) Filter for events with the specified event type. You can pass this query parameter
multiple times to select or exclude multiple event types. For example,
`event_type=default&event_type=outOfOffice` returns all events that are default or `OOO`, and excludes
any events that are `focusTime` or that have a `workingLocation`.

If you don't specify an event type, Nylas uses `default` to filter for regular events that don't have
another specific type.

notify_participants.name: notify_participants
notify_participants.description:
Filter for events matching the specified `notify_participants` setting.

Microsoft and iCloud do _not_ support `notify_participants=false`.

parent_id.name: parent_id
parent_id.description: (Microsoft and EWS only.) Use the ID of a folder to find all child folders it contains.

limit_contacts.name: limit
limit_contacts.description: The maximum number of objects to return. See [pagination](/docs/api/v3/ecc/#overview--pagination) for more information.
